value.title: Tumblr Posts (based on "Main Tumblr Feed")
value.description:
Given a Tumblr username, pulls recent posts through the API instead of RSS to detect post type, then reformats for correct RSS display and presents the result.  Useful if wanting to include ${type} as a part of a regex statement in the feed (ie: title = "${title} [tumblr:${type}]").

Intented as a drag-n-drop component; just "Favorite" then include in your mashup and enter your username.

Based on "Marre's tumblr".

items.description:
unhappyhipsters:

An added bonus with their open floorplan was that Dad finally learned his ABCs.

(Photo: Daniel Hennessy; Dwell)

Which sent me spiraling backwards in time to this after school classic whose title I found absolutely hilarious because of its absurdity. Then my mother informed me that not being able to read is, indeed, an actual problem afflicting adults. 

Innocence. Shattered. 


(Nov 19)

items.description:
When playing with my toys as a kid, I certainly didn’t picture this scary-ass monster working for Skeletor. After all, he looked more like this: 

I actually feel kinda sorry for him, like he has a learning disability. You know that one of those lasers he’s working on is just going to blow up in his face. 

Besides, what kind of a civilization invents laser guns, cyborgs, and hovercrafts before they invent pants? An AWESOME ONE, that’s what!

(Nov 16)

items.regular-body:
Google Sites is a great place to create a simple website or wiki at no cost, but it’s fairly restrictive when it comes to styles. Sometimes you want to make attachments at the bottom of the page a little more prominent, or call attention to an especially important link. Without the ability to use CSS files, this becomes a bit tricky, but there is a solution. 

  1. Visit a site like http://www.cssbuttongenerator.com/ and create a style. 
  2. Copy & paste the generated style into a CSS compressor like http://www.refresh-sf.com/yui/. 
  3. Copy the compressed style. 
  4. On your Google Sites page, edit your link in HTML view, adding a style attribute. 
  5. Paste the copied style from Step 3 as the style attribute’s value. 

To see this live, check out this example at my docs site.
items.description:
Google Sites is a great place to create a simple website or wiki at no cost, but it’s fairly restrictive when it comes to styles. Sometimes you want to make attachments at the bottom of the page a little more prominent, or call attention to an especially important link. Without the ability to use CSS files, this becomes a bit tricky, but there is a solution. 

  1. Visit a site like http://www.cssbuttongenerator.com/ and create a style. 
  2. Copy & paste the generated style into a CSS compressor like http://www.refresh-sf.com/yui/. 
  3. Copy the compressed style. 
  4. On your Google Sites page, edit your link in HTML view, adding a style attribute. 
  5. Paste the copied style from Step 3 as the style attribute’s value. 

To see this live, check out this example at my docs site. 


(Oct 28)

items.title: web2py. Easy as...
items.description:
When Google announced App Engine, I was intrigued. The ability to write code once and drop it onto an environment instantly accessible by anyone in the world was revolutionary. I was a Java programmer though, and App Engine was only offered in one flavor: Python. 

Python? I didn’t know much about it, but I figured I better start learning if I was going to use Google’s revolutionary architecture to change the world and become an instant billionaire. 

Fast-forward 3 years. App Engine’s new pricing policy has pretty much destroyed my chances of being a billionaire (not my inherent laziness), but the incentive it gave me to check out Python has really paid off. I love the language. It’s clean, it’s easy to understand, and it’s on the rise. Python web frameworks have sprung up over the past few years, and the most intriguing one is web2py. 

Web2py is a framework for rapid development of secure, portable web applications. It works on App Engine, MySQL, and Postgre, and it takes care of so many plumbing issues you’d think it was a Mario Brother. It’s even easy to “install”. Download it, unzip it, and run python2.5 web2py.py. That’s it. 

But I’m lazy (remember?). And forgetful. I can’t remember where the download page is, go there, get the file, unzip it in the right spot, create a directory structure, a .gitignore file, yada yada yada… 

So I did what any other lazy programmer would do. I wrote a script to do it all for me. 

GET IT, use it, and let me know what you think!

Related articles

6 Python Web Frameworks Compared

Photo courtesy of ginnerobot

(Oct 19)

Don’t burn bridges.

items.title: Reinstalling Sucks
items.description:
Software development is a fantastic field. It’s one of the few professions where you can think of an idea, build it, then use it. Nearly anything that can be imagined can be created.

I love discovering new tools that can help me realize those dreams. But I hate setting them up. There’s no bigger buzzkill than discovering you have to tear down your intricate development environment and rebuild it, all because of some incompatibility issue or limitation.

Oh, I installed this version of App Engine awhile back, but full text search is only available in the newest. I guess I’ll open my browser, go to their site, download the latest copy, untar it… Wait, first I have to uninstall the other version I have…

Blurgh.  

So I started building little “up” and “down” scripts to install and remove components, tools, SDKs, and whatever else I wanted. Over time, they got more sophisticated, until I found I needed - a script to build my scripts. 

Not… The Meta-Script! The Script to End All Scripts?! Surely it will become self-aware and destroy us all!

No, not really. It’s not that smart, but it does a great job of generating the skeleton I need to gracefully install and (when the time comes) remove the latest thing I’m messing with. 

Read this short write-up and grab the script. Let me know if it’s useful, and let me know if you’ve defeated The Meta-Script with something even better. 

Image courtesy of Zach Klein. 

(Oct 04)

Some people are saying that New York and New Jersey are jinxing the weather by putting a snowflake on the Super Bowl logo. I say you haven’t been to a real football game until you see rain turn into snow in front of your eyes in the oxygen-deprived nosebleed seats, ring the crystallized water from your gloves in the men’s room and linger at the hand dryers to ward off frostbite, then march through the slush to your car, turn it on, and blast the heat for 40 minutes just to regain feeling in your lower extremities - then get beer and wings at Anchor Bar. True football.

Bring it on, Northeast!

(Oct 03)
items.title: Photo:
items.photo-caption:
Some people are saying that New York and New Jersey are jinxing the weather by putting a snowflake on the Super Bowl logo. I say you haven’t been to a real football game until you see rain turn into snow in front of your eyes in the oxygen-deprived nosebleed seats, ring the crystallized water from your gloves in the men’s room and linger at the hand dryers to ward off frostbite, then march through the slush to your car, turn it on, and blast the heat for 40 minutes just to regain feeling in your lower extremities - then get beer and wings at Anchor Bar. True football.

Bring it on, Northeast!
